tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: The question requires calculating the torque-carrying capacity of two different cross-sections and finding their ratio. It involves understanding the relationship between torque, shear stress, and geometry for thin-walled sections, and requires multiple steps to calculate the area enclosed by each section. Since it requires understanding of multiple concepts and has a multi-step solution, the difficulty is medium and GPT-5.1 is recommended.

answer_validation.reasoning: For thin-walled single-cell closed sections under pure torsion, the shear flow is approximately uniform and given by $q = T/(2A_m)$, where $A_m$ is the area enclosed by the mean line. With strength as the only criterion and same material and thickness, both designs fail when the maximum shear stress (and hence maximum shear flow) reaches the same allowable value $q_{\max} = \tau_{\text{allow}} t$. Thus $T_{\max} = 2 A_m q_{\max}$ and the torque capacity is directly proportional to the enclosed area $A_m$. The ratio of maximum torques is therefore $T_B/T_A = A_{m,B}/A_{m,A}$. From the figure, Design A is a "racetrack" shape: a rectangle of length 4 cm and height 2 cm with a semicircular nose of radius 1 cm at the left and a flat end at the right. Design B has the same semicircular nose and overall 4 cm length and 2 cm height, but the aft end is tapered to a point 2 cm behind the rectangle, increasing the enclosed area. Computing the areas using the given dimensions (rectangle plus semicircle for A; rectangle plus semicircle plus isosceles triangle for B) gives $A_{m,A} \approx 8 + \tfrac{1}{2}\pi (1)^2$ and $A_{m,B} \approx 8 + \tfrac{1}{2}\pi (1)^2 + 2$, leading to $T_B/T_A \approx (10 + 0.5\pi)/(8 + 0.5\pi) \approx 1.21$. This matches the official key range 1.20 to 1.22.

step_by_step: Step 1: Recognize that both designs are thin-walled single-cell closed sections under pure torsion, made of the same material and thickness. Strength criterion means failure occurs when maximum shear stress reaches the same allowable value in both.

Step 2: For a thin-walled closed section with constant thickness, use Bredt-Batho: $T = 2 A_m q$, where $A_m$ is the area enclosed by the mean line and $q = \tau t$ is the shear flow. For a given allowable shear stress $\tau_{\text{allow}}$ and same thickness $t$, $q_{\max}$ is the same for both designs.
Step 3: Therefore, the maximum torque each design can carry is $T_{\max} = 2 A_m q_{\max}$, so the ratio of torque capacities is $T_B/T_A = A_{m,B}/A_{m,A}$. We only need the ratio of enclosed areas.

Step 4: From the figure, Design A consists of a 4 cm by 2 cm rectangle plus a semicircular nose of radius 1 cm. Its enclosed area is $A_{m,A} = 4 \times 2 + \tfrac{1}{2} \pi (1)^2 = 8 + 0.5\pi$ (cm$^2$).

Step 5: Design B has the same 4 cm by 2 cm rectangular middle and the same semicircular nose, but the aft end is tapered into a triangular tail of base 2 cm and height 2 cm (from the 2 cm dimension in the figure). Its area is $A_{\text{tail}} = \tfrac{1}{2} \times 2 \times 2 = 2$ cm$^2$. Thus $A_{m,B} = 8 + 0.5\pi + 2 = 10 + 0.5\pi$ (cm$^2$).

Step 6: Compute the ratio $T_B/T_A = A_{m,B}/A_{m,A} = (10 + 0.5\pi)/(8 + 0.5\pi)$. Using $\pi \approx 3.1416$, $0.5\pi \approx 1.5708$, so $A_{m,A} \approx 9.5708$ and $A_{m,B} \approx 11.5708$. The ratio is $11.5708/9.5708 \approx 1.21$.
Step 7: Round to two decimal places to get $T_B/T_A \approx 1.21$, which lies within the official answer range 1.20 to 1.22.

topic.name: Torsion of thin-walled closed sections
topic.syllabus_ref: Structures -> Bending, shear and torsion of thin-walled beams

concepts.name: Bredt-Batho formula for single-cell closed sections
Shear flow and shear stress in thin-walled members
Area enclosed by mean line and torsional strength

essential: Basic understanding of shear stress and shear flow in thin-walled members
Bredt-Batho torsion theory for thin-walled closed sections
Area calculation for simple plane figures (rectangle, circle, triangle)
Concept of failure based on maximum shear stress
helpful: Membrane analogy for torsion of thin-walled closed sections
Understanding of how geometry affects torsional rigidity and strength

Main Concept: requires: Shear stress and shear flow definitions in thin-walled structures
requires: Bredt-Batho relation between torque, area and shear flow
enables: Design optimization of closed-section beams for torsion
enables: Advanced analysis of multi-cell torsion in aircraft wings and fuselages

difficulty_factors: Requires recalling that torque capacity under strength criterion is proportional to enclosed area for same material and thickness
Needs correct interpretation of the geometry from the figure to compute areas
Students may confuse torsional stiffness (J) with strength and try to use angle-of-twist formulas instead

textbook_references.author: T.H.G. Megson
textbook_references.section: Single-cell closed sections and Bredt-Batho formula
textbook_references.text_snippet: For a thin-walled closed section of uniform thickness, the torque is related to the shear flow by $T = 2 A_m q$, where $A_m$ is the area enclosed by the median line of the wall.

textbook_references.author: T.H.G. Megson
textbook_references.text_snippet: Thin-walled beams are analysed by assuming constant stress through the thickness and using curvilinear coordinates around the perimeter.

video_references.book_reference: Megson - Aircraft Structures for Engineering Students
video_references.topic_covered: Membrane analogy and Bredt-Batho formula for thin-walled closed sections

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Use Bredt-Batho relation to link torque capacity to enclosed area, compute areas of both designs from geometry, then take ratio.
key_insights: For same material and thickness, strength-based torque capacity of a single-cell closed section is proportional to the area enclosed by the mean line.
The detailed distribution of wall length does not affect strength here; only the enclosed area matters.
Careful reading of the figure is crucial to identify the additional triangular area in Design B.

formulas_principles.name: Shear flow in thin-walled member
formulas_principles.conditions: Thin wall of thickness $t$ with approximately uniform shear stress $\tau$ through thickness
formulas_principles.relevance: Relates shear stress limit to maximum shear flow, which controls torque capacity.

formulas_principles.name: Bredt-Batho formula for single-cell closed section
formulas_principles.conditions: Thin-walled closed section with single cell and approximately constant shear flow along perimeter
formulas_principles.relevance: Core relation showing torque is proportional to enclosed area and shear flow.

formulas_principles.name: Area of rectangle
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to compute rectangular part of cross-sectional area.

formulas_principles.name: Area of semicircle
formulas_principles.relevance: Used for the semi-circular nose area in both designs.

formulas_principles.name: Area of triangle
formulas_principles.relevance: Used for the tapered tail area in Design B.

industry_examples: Design of aircraft fuselage frames and wing-box sections where closed thin-walled cells carry torsion from aerodynamic loads.
Optimization of helicopter tail boom or UAV fuselage cross-sections for maximum torsional strength with minimal weight.
specific_systems: Wing torsion box of a transport aircraft, where changing the planform of the box cross-section alters torsional strength.
Pressurized fuselage sections of regional jets, which must resist both internal pressure and torsion from asymmetric loading.
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Understanding that torsional strength of thin-walled closed sections scales with enclosed area helps engineers choose cross-sectional shapes that carry higher torque without increasing material thickness, leading to lighter and more efficient structures.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using torsional stiffness formula $T = G J \theta$ and comparing polar moments of inertia instead of using Bredt-Batho and enclosed area for strength.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They recall solid-shaft torsion from basic mechanics and confuse stiffness (angle of twist) with strength (stress limit).
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: When you see 'thin-walled closed section' and 'strength as the only criterion', immediately think of Bredt-Batho: torque capacity $\propto A_m$ for same $t$ and material.
common_mistakes.consequence: Gives an incorrect ratio because $J$ for thin-walled sections is not the governing parameter for failure here.

common_mistakes.mistake: Ignoring the triangular tail in Design B or misreading its dimensions, leading to equal areas or a wrong additional area.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Under time pressure, they skim the figure and assume both shapes have the same area since overall length and height look similar.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Carefully trace the mean line of the wall and decompose the enclosed region into standard shapes (rectangle, semicircle, triangle) before writing any numbers.
common_mistakes.consequence: Area ratio becomes 1 or another incorrect value, giving a wrong torque ratio.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using outer dimensions directly without realizing that for same thickness the mean-line area is effectively the same as the inner/outer area to first order.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Confusion about 'mean area' and whether to subtract thickness.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember that when comparing two shapes with identical thickness, the small correction from using mean vs outer dimensions cancels in the ratio.
common_mistakes.consequence: Usually small numerical error, but can cause slight deviation if thickness is not negligible.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: "Torque in a thin box is Twice Area times q"
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Remembering Bredt-Batho: $T = 2 A_m q$ for single-cell closed sections
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use whenever you see thin-walled closed sections under torsion.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: For thin closed shells, Strength \u2248 Space inside
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Torque capacity is proportional to enclosed area for same material and thickness
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Helps recall that geometry (area) controls torsional strength.

flashcards.front: What is the Bredt-Batho relation between torque T, enclosed area $A_m$ and shear flow q for a single-cell thin-walled closed section?
flashcards.back: For a single-cell thin-walled closed section with approximately uniform shear flow: $T = 2 A_m q$, where $A_m$ is the area enclosed by the mean line and $q$ is the shear flow.

flashcards.front: Two thin-walled closed sections have the same material and thickness. Under a strength (shear stress) limit, what geometric quantity mainly governs their torque capacity?
flashcards.back: The area enclosed by the mean line $A_m$. For same thickness and allowable shear stress, $T_{\max} \propto A_m$.

flashcards.front: A thin-walled closed section is modified to increase its enclosed area by 15% without changing thickness or material. Approximately how much does its torque capacity change (strength-based)?
flashcards.back: Torque capacity increases by about 15%, since $T_{\max} \propto A_m$ for same allowable shear stress and thickness.

flashcards.front: In torsion of thin-walled closed sections, when should you NOT use $T = G J \theta$ as the primary design equation?
flashcards.back: When the question is about strength (maximum allowable shear stress) rather than stiffness (angle of twist). For strength, use Bredt-Batho and shear stress limits instead.

real_world_context.application: Design of aircraft wing torsion boxes
real_world_context.industry_example: Changing the cross-sectional shape of a wing-box from a nearly rectangular cell to a more trapezoidal or tapered shape can increase the enclosed area and thus torsional strength without adding material.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Insufficient torsional strength can lead to structural failure under maneuver or gust loads, compromising safety.

real_world_context.industry_example: Tail booms are often thin-walled closed tubes; designers may choose oval or tapered cross-sections to maximize torsional strength for transmitting tail rotor torque.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: If the boom cannot safely carry rotor torque, it may twist excessively or fail, leading to loss of control.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Identify that both shapes are thin-walled closed sections; recall $T \propto A_m$ for same material and thickness. Quickly decompose each shape into simple areas and compute the ratio. Minimal algebra, high scoring.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If unsure but you see that Design B encloses more area than A, you know $T_B/T_A$ must be greater than 1 but not huge (likely 1.1–1.3). Choose a value in that range.
exam_strategy.time_management: Aim to finish within 2–3 minutes: 1 minute to interpret the figure and 1–2 minutes for area calculations and ratio.

search_keywords: shear flow in single-cell closed sections
GATE AE torsion thin walled closed section problem
torsional strength vs stiffness thin-walled box

alternative_methods.name: Membrane analogy visualization
alternative_methods.description: Imagine a soap film or membrane stretched over the cross-section and pressurized. The torque corresponds to twice the volume under the membrane, which is proportional to the enclosed area for a given maximum membrane height (related to shear stress). Comparing volumes (areas) gives the same torque ratio.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Provides strong physical intuition for why torque capacity scales with area. Cons: Less direct for quick numerical calculation in exams.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful when building conceptual understanding of torsion in thin-walled closed sections.

connections_to_other_subjects.Mechanics of Materials: Extends basic torsion of solid circular shafts to thin-walled closed sections, highlighting differences between stiffness and strength criteria.
connections_to_other_subjects.Aerospace Structures: Forms the basis for analyzing torsion in fuselage shells and wing-boxes, which are key structural components.
connections_to_other_subjects.Structural Optimization: Area-based strength scaling is important when optimizing cross-sectional shapes for weight and performance.

syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Bending, shear and torsion of thin-walled beams; shear flow in open and closed sections
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: Excellent conceptual question linking thin-walled torsion theory with geometric design considerations; appropriate for testing understanding of Bredt-Batho and area dependence.

rag_quality.notes: RAG provided general background on torsion of thin-walled sections and membrane analogy (Megson, Anup Ghosh), but not this specific geometry. Core solution relied on standard Bredt-Batho theory and area calculations from internal knowledge, with RAG mainly supporting conceptual context.

future_questions_potential: Ask for the ratio of angles of twist (stiffness comparison) between the two designs, requiring evaluation of effective torsion constant $J_{\text{eff}}$ using $J_{\text{eff}} = 4 A_m^2 t / S_m$.
Introduce non-uniform thickness along the perimeter and ask students to compute torque capacity using $\theta = (1/(2 A_m G)) \int (q/t) ds$.
Extend to a multi-cell version of the same cross-section and ask for shear flow distribution in each cell under a given torque.
Combine torsion with bending and ask for failure assessment using a suitable failure theory (e.g., maximum shear stress criterion).

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: Two designs A and B, shown in the figure, are proposed for a thin-walled closed section that is expected to carry only torque. Both A and B have a semi-circular nose, and are made of the same material with a wall thickness of 1 mm. With strength as the only criterion for failure, the ratio of maximum torque that B can support to the maximum torque that A can support is__ (rounded off to two decimal places).
